item.title: Testing in Spring Boot With Junit and Mockito
item.description:
In October 2018 and March 2019, Boeing’s 737 MAX ‚úàÔ∏è was involved in two fatal crashes resulting in the loss of 346 lives as well as billions in fines, lawsuits and a lasting damage to Boeing’s reputation. The cause of these crashes: faulty sensor data caused the MCAS (Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System) to activate inappropriately. The software wasn’t tested adequately against single-sensor failure.

It’s important to note that unit testing alone would not have saved the 737 MAX but had the MCAS system been more rigorously tested, its assumptions may have been questioned with more scrutiny and raised flags earlier.

item.title: Deploying Our Fantasy Ledger to the Cloud
item.description:
Previously, we built a fantasy ledger application in Java Spring Boot, whipped up a frontend and hooked it up to an in-memory SQL database all while sticking to the principles of MVC.

That’s great and all, but the only way to actually interact with our app is by running it locally, which can be a bit of a hassle ü§¶ to set up every time. item.title: Building a Tiny Cron Scheduler With Go
item.description: If you’re anything like me, you’ve probably got a bunch of scheduled tasks running in the cloud whether it’s automation, IoT projects, data processing or just random experiments. My go-to approach has been to dockerize mini servers and deploy them on platforms like GCP or AWS. But getting something up and running on Cloud Run or Lambda isn’t as lightweight as it sounds. You still need to push images to a registry, wire up an API gateway and set up a scheduler like Cloud Scheduler on GCP.
